question_text:
Lucia drew a scale drawing of the elementary school. In real life, the school yard is 75 metres wide. It is 135 millimetres wide in the drawing. What scale did Lucia use?
9 millimetres : _ metres
solution:
Write the ratio of the width of the school yard in the drawing to the width of the actual school yard. Write the ratio in fraction form.
$\frac{135 \text{mm}}{75 \text{m}}$

Simplify the fraction.
$\frac{135 \text{mm} \div 15}{75 \text{m} \div 15} = \frac{9 \text{mm}}{5 \text{m}}$
The scale of the drawing is 9 millimetres : 5 metres.

question_text:
Bill, a professional golfer, is playing on a golf tour. The next two stops are 4 centimetres apart on a map of the tour. How far apart are the next two stops in real life if the map uses a scale of 2 centimetres = 1 kilometre?
_ kilometres
solution:
Write a ratio that represents the scale of the map in centimetres to kilometres:
$\frac{2}{1}$

Write a ratio that relates the centimetres between the next two stops on the map to the kilometres between the next two stops in real life:
$\frac{4}{d}$

Use those ratios to set up a proportion and solve.
$\frac{2}{1}=\frac{4}{d}$

Multiply both sides by $d$.
$\frac{2}{1}d = \frac{4}{d}d$

Simplify.
$2d = 4$

Divide both sides by 2.
$d=2$
The next two stops are 2 kilometres apart in real life.

question_text:
Will measured a shopping centre and made a scale drawing. The scale of the drawing was 1 centimetre : 3 metres. The parking lot is 12 centimetres in the drawing. How wide is the actual parking lot?
_ metres
solution:
Write the scale of the drawing as a fraction:
$\frac{1\text{cm}}{3\text{m}}$

Write an equivalent fraction with 12 centimetres as the numerator:
$\frac{1 \text{cm} \times 12}{3 \text{m} \times 12} = \frac{12 \text{cm}}{36 \text{m}}$
The actual parking lot is 36 metres wide.

question_text:
Bill, a professional golfer, is playing on a golf tour. The next two stops are 40 centimetres apart on a map of the tour. How far apart are the next two stops in real life if the map uses a scale of 8 centimetres = 80 kilometre?
_ kilometres
solution:
Write a ratio that represents the scale of the map in centimetres to kilometres:
$\frac{8}{80}$

Write a ratio that relates the centimetres between the next two stops on the map to the kilometres between the next two stops in real life:
$\frac{40}{d}$

Use those ratios to set up a proportion and solve.
$\frac{8}{80}=\frac{40}{d}$

Multiply both sides by $d$.
$\frac{8}{80}d = \frac{40}{d}d$

Simplify.
$2d = 40$

Divide both sides by 8.
$d=8$
The next two stops are 8 kilometres apart in real life.

_ kilometres
solution:
Write a ratio that represents the scale of the map in centimetres to kilometres:
$\frac{136}{20}$

Write a ratio that relates the centimetres between the next two stops on the map to the kilometres between the next two stops in real life:
$\frac{17}{d}$

Use those ratios to set up a proportion and solve.
$\frac{136}{20}=\frac{17}{d}$

Multiply both sides by $d$.
$\frac{136}{20}d = \frac{17}{d}d$

Simplify.
$2d = 17$

Divide both sides by 136.
$d=136$
The next two stops are 136 kilometres apart in real life.

question_text:
Lucia drew a scale drawing of the elementary school. In real life, the school yard is 13 metres wide. It is 136 millimetres wide in the drawing. What scale did Lucia use?
129 millimetres : _ metres
solution:
Write the ratio of the width of the school yard in the drawing to the width of the actual school yard. Write the ratio in fraction form.
$\frac{136 \text{mm}}{13 \text{m}}$

Simplify the fraction.
$\frac{136 \text{mm} \div 15}{13 \text{m} \div 15} = \frac{129 \text{mm}}{5 \text{m}}$
The scale of the drawing is 129 millimetres : 5 metres.

question_text:
Bill, a professional golfer, is playing on a golf tour. The next two stops are 13 centimetres apart on a map of the tour. How far apart are the next two stops in real life if the map uses a scale of 16 centimetres = 77 kilometre?
_ kilometres
solution:
Write a ratio that represents the scale of the map in centimetres to kilometres:
$\frac{16}{77}$

Write a ratio that relates the centimetres between the next two stops on the map to the kilometres between the next two stops in real life:
$\frac{13}{d}$

Use those ratios to set up a proportion and solve.
$\frac{16}{77}=\frac{13}{d}$

Multiply both sides by $d$.
$\frac{16}{77}d = \frac{13}{d}d$

Simplify.
$2d = 13$

Divide both sides by 16.
$d=16$
The next two stops are 16 kilometres apart in real life.

question_text:
Lucia drew a scale drawing of the elementary school. In real life, the school yard is 54 metres wide. It is 17 millimetres wide in the drawing. What scale did Lucia use?
43 millimetres : _ metres
solution:
Write the ratio of the width of the school yard in the drawing to the width of the actual school yard. Write the ratio in fraction form.
$\frac{17 \text{mm}}{54 \text{m}}$

Simplify the fraction.
$\frac{17 \text{mm} \div 15}{54 \text{m} \div 15} = \frac{43 \text{mm}}{5 \text{m}}$
The scale of the drawing is 43 millimetres : 5 metres.

question_text:
Will measured a shopping centre and made a scale drawing. The scale of the drawing was 33 centimetre : 66 metres. The parking lot is 132 centimetres in the drawing. How wide is the actual parking lot?
_ metres
solution:
Write the scale of the drawing as a fraction:
$\frac{33\text{cm}}{66\text{m}}$

Write an equivalent fraction with 132 centimetres as the numerator:
$\frac{33 \text{cm} \times 132}{66 \text{m} \times 132} = \frac{132 \text{cm}}{36 \text{m}}$
The actual parking lot is 36 metres wide.

question_text:
Bill, a professional golfer, is playing on a golf tour. The next two stops are 7 centimetres apart on a map of the tour. How far apart are the next two stops in real life if the map uses a scale of 63 centimetres = 75 kilometre?
_ kilometres
solution:
Write a ratio that represents the scale of the map in centimetres to kilometres:
$\frac{63}{75}$

Write a ratio that relates the centimetres between the next two stops on the map to the kilometres between the next two stops in real life:
$\frac{7}{d}$

Use those ratios to set up a proportion and solve.
$\frac{63}{75}=\frac{7}{d}$

Multiply both sides by $d$.
$\frac{63}{75}d = \frac{7}{d}d$

Simplify.
$2d = 7$

Divide both sides by 63.
$d=63$
The next two stops are 63 kilometres apart in real life.

question_text:
Bill, a professional golfer, is playing on a golf tour. The next two stops are 84 centimetres apart on a map of the tour. How far apart are the next two stops in real life if the map uses a scale of 42 centimetres = 122 kilometre?
_ kilometres
solution:
Write a ratio that represents the scale of the map in centimetres to kilometres:
$\frac{42}{122}$

Write a ratio that relates the centimetres between the next two stops on the map to the kilometres between the next two stops in real life:
$\frac{84}{d}$

Use those ratios to set up a proportion and solve.
$\frac{42}{122}=\frac{84}{d}$

Multiply both sides by $d$.
$\frac{42}{122}d = \frac{84}{d}d$

Simplify.
$2d = 84$

Divide both sides by 42.
$d=42$
The next two stops are 42 kilometres apart in real life.

question_text:
Will measured a shopping centre and made a scale drawing. The scale of the drawing was 15 centimetre : 16 metres. The parking lot is 6 centimetres in the drawing. How wide is the actual parking lot?
_ metres
solution:
Write the scale of the drawing as a fraction:
$\frac{15\text{cm}}{16\text{m}}$

Write an equivalent fraction with 6 centimetres as the numerator:
$\frac{15 \text{cm} \times 6}{16 \text{m} \times 6} = \frac{6 \text{cm}}{36 \text{m}}$
The actual parking lot is 36 metres wide.
